docTitle.titlePart: TITLE: 3-D Electronic Imaging of Fabric Qualities by On-Line Yarn Data

front.note:
INVESTIGATORS:
Moon W. Suh (Leader), Warren Jasper and Jae L. Woo (NCSU),
Arkady Cherkassky (Shenkar College-Israel)
STUDENTS:
front.div:
PROJECT GOALS
The primary objective is to design and develop a control system for electronically imaging the
quality attributes (basis weight, appearance uniformity, physical properties, etc.) of woven and
knitted fabrics directly from an on-line yarn mass /diameter measurement system without having
to go through the actual fabrication processes. Such a system is to facilitate optimal yarn and
fabric development to achieve the desired uniformity or aesthetically pleasing "non-random
random effects (chaos)" within the yarn and the resulting fabrics under the data-rich modern
manufacturing environment. The secondary objectives are: 1) to perfect the data reduction and
expansion techniques that are amenable to mapping and imaging the micro and macro
dimensions of the resulting fabrics suitable for quality prediction, modification and mapping in
time domain and two-dimensional spatial domain, and 2) to perfect a "data fusion" technology
based on the optical and capacitor type measurements of yarn diameters and yarn density
profiles suitable for achieving the primary objective of this study.
ABSTRACT
We are developing 3-D prediction models for fabric appearance and other quality attributes by
using the data captured from any on-line yarn measurement system currently in use. Such a 3-D
imaging system is most useful for fabric development and textile process control. We are
developing mathematical theories and the corresponding algorithms for image simulation, data
reduction and data mapping onto structural geometry of woven and knitted fabrics, in both micro
and macro scales. The electronic imaging will be done on the quality attributes (basis weight,
appearance uniformity, physical properties, etc.) of woven and knitted fabrics directly from an
on-line yarn diameter of mass measurement system. We are doing this without having to knit or
weave the real fabrics. Such a system, if perfected, is expected to economize and improve the
efficiencies of product development and quality control.
